Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Manufacturing Workshop: Preparing the Next Generation of Women of Color Engineering Researchers

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Women of color are underrepresented throughout the engineering professoriate. This project is developing a special professional development workshop for women faculty of color to broaden their participation in advanced manufacturing areas. The main objectives of the workshop are to: 1) increase awareness of innovation needs and relevance of advanced manufacturing to the U.S., 2) promote a networking platform that brings women of color engineering faculty together to stimulate potential collaborations on advanced manufacturing, and 3) share strategies for overcoming obstacles that often hinder the career advancement of women of color faculty in engineering.

The research-driven workshop will focus on emerging advanced manufacturing areas, with an emphasis on the design of materials, additive manufacturing, and hybrid manufacturing. Workshop participants will have access to state of the art equipment available in the Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering Department at Iowa State University, and training will be offered through modular hands-on activities that are supplemented with theoretical instruction. The workshop will host up to twenty-five women of color engineering faculty from various universities around the country, along with ten to fifteen undergraduate students from Iowa State University. The participants will engage in a "speed mentoring" activity, where they will have the unique opportunity to develop and discuss their specific career plans in one-on-one sessions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organized by the PI, Iris V. Rivero, the NSF funded Advanced Manufacturing Workshop - Preparing the Next Generation of Researchers was a strategic effort that brought together women and underrepresented minority (URM) women in engineering academia from across the country to engage and prepare them in fundamental engineering research in advanced manufacturing - The Next Generation of Researchers. The workshop brought attention to emerging subject areas in advanced manufacturing such as design of materials, additive and hybrid manufacturing which constitute the foundation of transformative research in biomedical, automotive, and aerospace fields. More importantly, the workshop was an endeavor to begin breaking cultural stereotypes and increase the involvement of these demographical groups in the field of manufacturing. Obstacles deterring the involvement and advancement of women and URM women in the engineering professoriate and the field of manufacturing include the perception of "cultural" intellectual capabilities, limited access to state-of-the-art resources directly impacting research support, lack of advancement opportunities, "chilly" environment, structural impediments, and perception of manufacturing being a field lacking a bright future. Therefore, the objectives of the workshop included to: 1) bring awareness of innovation needs and relevance of advanced manufacturing to the U.S.; 2) promote a networking platform that brings women and URM women faculty in engineering together to stimulate interaction and potential collaborations in advanced manufacturing research; and 3) establish strategies to counteract obstacles that hinder the career advancement of URM women faculty in engineering. To achieve these goals presentations were delivered by invited speakers focusing in the discussion of manufacturing research subjects, while the PI designed interactive professional development activities where the subjects of diversity, race, and gender in the engineering professoriate were discussed with invited panelists.

Throughout the two-and-a-half-day duration of the workshop participants were encouraged to carry out small-group discussion in subjects of their interest that could merge with the research subject of manufacturing. For that purpose, the invited speaker-led presentations on manufacturing research were intermixed with the professional development panels and downtime to allow for groups to form and interact. With regards to the manufacturing research discussions, they were initiated by providing an overview of polymers and metals used in the fabrication of components and structures via additive manufacturing techniques. This subject was followed by an interactive session introducing the subject of Hybrid Manufacturing. Lastly, the subject of Additive Manufacturing was presented by emphasizing the multidisciplinarity of research projects carried out within this field. While the professional development activities emphasized the subject of intersectionality, and stimulated discussion identifying opportunities for career advancement. In addition, invited speakers currently in administrative roles, guided candid dialogues highlighting the enrichment to the profession that inclusion provides, and identified strategies for successful career progression in academia. The last day of the workshop participants had the opportunity to interact with program directors from NSF, DoD, and DoE, and present to them the research concepts developed during the workshop.

From advertising the workshop through the Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineering (IISE) and the Society of Manufacturing Engineers (SME), and reaching out to professional contacts in administrative roles at various universities, a total of 17 participants were accepted to the workshop. Unfortunately, 4 participants were not able to attend the workshop as a consequence of travel disruptions caused by Hurricane Maria. The application process consisted of submission of a packet that included: a statement of research, and an NSF style biosketch. Screening of the applications and selection of participants was based on the thoroughness of the research and career plan presented in the application, as this information provided an indication of the level of commitment and interest of the applicants in advanced manufacturing research.

To evaluate progress towards the accomplishment of the established objectives for the workshop two sets of surveys were designed and conducted with the participants. A pre-workshop survey that assessed the state of the participants prior to the workshop with regards to research priorities; and a post-workshop survey that assessed the effect on the participants' knowledge in advanced manufacturing research priorities after the workshop, and their awareness of advancement in academic career opportunities for women and women of color in engineering. Results from the surveys are summarized as follow: first, attendees were very satisfied with how the workshop was set-up, with nearly all attendees indicating agreement or strong agreement for the workshop activities effectiveness, resource usefulness, and the information provided. Second, attendees all indicated some level of agreement with statements regarding contacts made and intended to be kept, and the majority of attendees found the workshop to be beneficial for future research and support.

At the end, the main outcome of the workshop was achieved by providing a platform for women and URM women in engineering academia to devise unique research opportunities in manufacturing within multidisciplinary teams. Such interactions should contribute to the academic promotion goals of this population.
